source: Archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby have also missed out. Cycling - which brought Team GB 12 medals in Rio - has had its funding cut by more than £4m to £25.98m. Badminton England chief executive Adrian Christy said he was "staggered" by the "incomprehensible" decision to remove the sport's funding. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports - £2m less than the record £347m allocated for the Rio Games. As a result, UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals, and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Britain enjoyed unprecedented success at Rio 2016, with the Olympics yielding 67 medals and the Paralympics 147. Chair of UK Sport Rod Carr said the government, which provides funding alongside National Lottery money, has "confirmed its commitment" for Tokyo 2020. He added: "These are critical funding decisions for sports to take them on their journey to Tokyo 2020 and beyond so the historic success at Rio can be maintained." Badminton, which was set a target of winning a medal in Rio, is the only sport that earned a podium place in the summer to have its funding removed. Marcus Ellis and Chris Langridge took bronze in the men's doubles after the sport was given £5.74m in the last cycle. Christy said the decision represents a "catastrophic impact on the sport" and Badminton England would "fight for the hopes and dreams" of its players. "How can you return from the best Games for more than a decade, in a year where our players have demonstrated world-class performances and where we can demonstrate the journey to Tokyo is on track, only be to have every penny of investment withdrawn?" he said. "What have we done wrong?" added GB Badminton's performance director Jon Austin. Judo, which was given the same target as badminton and also claimed one bronze medal, has had its funding increased slightly. Liz Nicholl, CEO of UK Sport, said the decision to cut funding was not taken lightly. "We would like to invest in every sport but the reality is we have to prioritise to protect and enhance the medal potential," she said. "If we under-invest across the board then the British teams will ultimately underperform at the Games and medal success will be put at risk." Sports minister Tracey Crouch added: "UK Sport's approach to elite sport has proven successful in Beijing, London and Rio and the ambition to win more medals in Tokyo is a bold one that, if achieved, would mean a sensational summer of sport in 2020." Basketball had its funding withdrawn in 2014 - and handball and volleyball lost theirs in 2012 - but say a UK Sport review last year to build "performance pathways for future success" was supposed to be aimed at such sports. A British Basketball statement, in conjunction with volleyball and handball, said: "It appears that UK Sport has no interest in team sports and in particular refuses to take responsibility for the need to fund their performance development, which was identified in its own review. "With UK Sport's investment budget approaching £350m, it borders on intransigence to pass responsibility to government and other funding bodies who are not set up to fund the development of high-performance sport." UK Sport says investment in the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed. Baseball/softball will return to the programme, with karate, skateboard, sports climbing and surfing also added, while Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton join the Paralympic programme. UK Sport says funding will be determined "following further exploration of medal potential", with £9m of the £345m total still to be allocated. Liam Carroll, head coach of the GB baseball team, said: "The key to unlocking our potential is investment and I'm pleased that UK Sport has left the door open. "We look forward to the opportunity to impress upon them that getting behind Great Britain Baseball can extend their tremendous track record of investing in Olympic medal contenders."
summary: The passage discusses funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports in the UK for the Tokyo 2020 Games. UK Sport has allocated a total of £345m for 31 sports, which is £2m less than the funding for the Rio Games. Notable sports that have had their funding cut include archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton. Cycling, which brought 12 medals in Rio, has had its funding cut by more than £4m. Badminton England is particularly upset about the decision, as they had a podium place in the summer and were set a target of winning a medal in Rio. Judo, which also claimed one bronze medal, has had its funding increased slightly. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo, aiming to maintain the success at Rio 2016. Sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball have previously had their funding withdrawn and are critical of UK Sport's approach to team sports. The funding for the five

summary: The UK government has cut funding for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, with cycling's funding reduced by over £4m. Badminton England's CEO expressed shock at the decision, as the sport had previously won a bronze medal in Rio 2016. UK Sport has set a target of 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Tokyo 2020. The government and National Lottery funding will continue, but the allocation for the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed. The decision to cut funding was made to prioritize and protect medal potential, with the remaining £9m of the £345m total still to be allocated.

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the passage:

UK Sport has announced funding decisions for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics, with a total investment of £345m across 31 sports. This is £2m less than the funding for Rio 2016. Some sports, including badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, have had their funding cut or removed entirely. Cycling has seen a significant reduction in funding. The decision has been met with criticism from affected sports, particularly badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio. UK Sport defends its decisions, stating the need to prioritize medal potential. The funding body has set medal targets for Team GB in Tokyo: 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. New Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020 are still under consideration for funding allocation. The government and National Lottery continue to support the funding program, aiming to maintain Britain's recent Olympic and Paralympic successes.

summary: The UK government and National Lottery have committed funding for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, totalling £345 million, with the aim of maintaining Britain's success at the Tokyo 2020 Games. This is a slight decrease from the previous funding allocation for Rio. Cycling, despite its strong medal performance in Rio, has seen a funding cut. Badminton, however, has had its funding removed entirely, despite winning a medal in Rio, with its representatives expressing shock and disappointment. UK Sport justifies the funding decisions by prioritizing sports with higher medal potential, while acknowledging the need to invest in a broader range of sports for future success.

summary:
The passage discusses funding cuts for certain Olympic and Paralympic sports in preparation for the Tokyo 2020 Games. Key points include:

- Funding reductions for archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby.
- Cycling's funding cut by over £4 million to £25.98 million.
- Badminton's funding completely removed despite achieving a bronze medal in Rio.
- Total investment reduced to £345 million, £2 million less than Rio's record £347 million.
- UK Sport targets 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Tokyo.
- Some sports, like judo, received slight funding increases.
- UK Sport justifies cuts by prioritizing medal potential and protecting overall performance.
- Criticism from affected sports about the decision-making process and funding allocation.

summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

UK Sport has allocated £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, a decrease of £2m from the Rio 2016 Games. The investment will target 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, has had its funding cut, while judo has had its funding increased slightly. UK Sport's chair, Rod Carr, says the funding decisions are critical for sports to maintain their historic success at Rio. The decision to cut funding for badminton has been met with criticism from the sport's leaders, who say it will have a catastrophic impact on the sport. UK Sport says it must prioritize sports with the highest medal potential, but has left the door open for other sports, including baseball, which will return to the Olympic programme after a 13-year absence.

He added: "These are critical funding decisions for sports to take them on their journey to Tokyo 2020 and beyond so the historic success at Rio can be maintained." Badminton, which was set a target of winning a medal in Rio, is the only sport that earned a podium place in the summer to have its funding removed. Marcus Ellis and Chris Langridge took bronze in the men's doubles after the sport was given £5.74m in the last cycle. Christy said the decision represents a "catastrophic impact on the sport" and Badminton England would "fight for the hopes and dreams" of its players. "How can you return from the best Games for more than a decade, in a year where our players have demonstrated world-class performances and where we can demonstrate the journey to Tokyo is on track, only be to have every penny of investment withdrawn?" he said. "What have we done wrong?" added GB Badminton's performance director Jon Austin. Judo, which was given the same target as badminton and also claimed one bronze medal, has had its funding increased slightly. Liz Nicholl, CEO of UK Sport, said the decision to cut funding was not taken lightly. "We would like to invest in every sport but the reality is we have to prioritise to protect and enhance the medal potential," she said. "If we under-invest across the board then the British teams will ultimately underperform at the Games and medal success will be put at risk." Sports minister Tracey Crouch added: "UK Sport's approach to elite sport has proven successful in Beijing, London and Rio and the ambition to win more medals in Tokyo is a bold one that, if achieved, would mean a sensational summer of sport in 2020." Basketball had its funding withdrawn in 2014 - and handball and volleyball lost theirs in 2012 - but say a UK Sport review last year to build "performance pathways for future success" was supposed to be aimed at such sports. A British Basketball statement, in conjunction with volleyball and handball, said: "It appears that UK Sport has no interest in team sports and in particular refuses to take responsibility for the need to fund their performance development, which was identified in its own review. "With UK Sport's investment budget approaching £350m, it borders on intransigence to pass responsibility to government and other funding bodies who are not set up to fund the development of high-performance sport." UK Sport says investment in the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed. Baseball/softball will return to the programme, with karate, skateboard, sports climbing and surfing also added, while Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton join the Paralympic programme. UK Sport says funding will be determined "following further exploration of medal potential", with £9m of the £345m total still to be allocated. Liam Carroll, head coach of the GB baseball team, said: "The key to unlocking our potential is investment and I'm pleased that UK Sport has left the door open. "We look forward to the opportunity to impress upon them that getting behind Great Britain Baseball can extend their tremendous track record of investing in Olympic medal contenders."
summary: UK Sport has announced funding for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, totaling £345 million. This is £2 million less than the record £347 million allocated for the Rio Games. The funding decisions were made based on medal potential, with the goal of achieving 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, is the only sport that had its funding removed, despite its success. Other sports, such as basketball, handball, and volleyball, have also had their funding withdrawn in recent years. UK Sport is still determining funding for the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020, including baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton.

summary: The UK government has cut funding for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton. Cycling has also had its funding reduced. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, with a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Badminton and judo, which both won bronze medals in Rio, have had their funding removed and slightly increased, respectively. UK Sport says the decision to cut funding was made to prioritize and enhance medal potential. Basketball, handball, and volleyball had their funding withdrawn in previous years. The funding for the new sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed.

summary: The passage discusses the allocation of funding for Olympic and Paralympic sports by UK Sport for the Tokyo 2020 Games. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have lost funding, while cycling's budget was reduced by over £4m. Badminton, despite winning a bronze medal in Rio, had its funding completely removed, a decision criticized by Badminton England's chief executive. Overall, £345m will be invested in 31 sports, £2m less than for the Rio Games. UK Sport aims for Team GB to win 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Despite the cuts, the government remains committed to funding. Funding for new sports added for Tokyo 2020, including baseball/softball, karate, and others, is still pending based on medal potential.
